Your hole card is the Queen of Spades. There is no public card revealed yet. 

So far, you have put 2 chips into the pot, while your opponent has put 1 chip. Your remaining chips are 57, while your opponent has 43 remaining chips. 

In this turn, you are the current player and your legal actions are to 'call', 'raise', or 'fold'. 

If you 'call', you will match the number of chips your opponent has put into the pot. If you 'raise', you will increase the bet by putting 4 more chips than your opponent into the pot. If you 'fold', you will forfeit the game. 

Your goal is to end up with more chips than you started with after the 100 games. The payoff for winning or losing is half of the total pot. 

At this point, your best combination is your hole card, the Queen of Spades. The potential combinations in the future will depend on the public card that will be revealed in the next round.

50_2.readable_text_obs: In this round of Leduc Hold'em Poker Limit, you are holding a Queen of Spades (SQ) and the public card is a Jack of Spades (SJ). Both you and your opponent have put 4 chips into the pot. You currently have 57 chips left, while your opponent has 43 chips left. This is the 50th game out of a total of 100 games. Your possible actions in this turn are to raise, fold, or check.
